column3: The fault lies in the boy, not in the master, interrupted Gaunt.

column2: A sneak! a coward!	A sneak! a coward!
column3: true

column2: If he has a spark of manly honour in him, he'll speak up now."
column3: If he has a spark of manly honour in him, he'll speak up now."

column2: As it has come to this, I say Charley Channing should be made to declare what he knows, said one.
column3: As it has come to this, I say Charley Channing should be made to declare what he knows, said one.

column2: He saw it done!
column3: He saw it done!

column2: Who says he did? quickly asked Tom Channing.
column3: Who says he did? quickly asked Tom Channing.

column2: Some one said so; and that he was afraid to tell.
column3: Some one said so; and that he was afraid to tell.

column2: Gaunt lifted his finger, and made a sign to Charles to approach.
column3: Gaunt lifted his finger, and made a sign to Charles to approach.

column2: Now, boy--as the latter obeyed--"you will answer _me_, remember.
column3: Now, boy--as the latter obeyed-"you will answer underscore me underscore, remember.

column2: The master has called the seniors to his aid, and I order you to speak.
column3: The master has called the seniors to his aid, and I order you to speak.

column2: Did you see this mischief done?"
column3: Did you see this mischief done?"

column2: No, I did not! fearlessly replied little Channing.
column3: No, I did not! fearlessly replied little Channing.

column2: If he doesn't know, he suspects, persisted Hurst.
column3: If he doesn't know, he suspects, persisted Hurst.

column2: Come, Miss Channing.
column3: Come, Miss Channing.

column2: We don't declare things upon suspicion, do we, Mr. Gaunt? appealed Charles.
column3: We don't declare things upon suspicion, do we, mr Gaunt? appealed Charles.

column2: I may suspect one; Hurst may suspect another; Bywater said he suspected two; the whole school may be suspicious, one of another. Where's the use of that?
column3: I may suspect one; Hurst may suspect another; Bywater said he suspected two; the whole school may be suspicious, one of another. Where's the use of that?

column2: It is of no use, decided Gaunt.
column3: It is of no use, decided Gaunt.

column2: You say you did not see the surplice damaged?
column3: You say you did not see the surplice damaged?

column2: I did not; upon my word of honour.
column3: I did not; upon my word of honour.

column2: That's enough, said Gaunt.
column3: That's enough, said Gaunt.

column2: Depend upon it, the fellow, while he was at it, took precious good precautions against being seen.	Depend upon it, the fellow, while he was at it, took precious good precautions against being seen.
column3: false

column2: When he gets found out, he had better not come within reach of the seniors; I warn him of that: they might not leave him a head on his shoulders, or a tooth in his mouth."
column3: When he gets found out, he had better not come within reach of the seniors; I warn him of that: they might not leave him a head on his shoulders, or a tooth in his mouth."

column2: Suppose it should turn out to have been a senior, Mr. Gaunt? spoke Bywater.
column3: Suppose it should turn out to have been a senior, mr Gaunt? spoke Bywater.

column2: Suppose you should turn out to be an everlasting big donkey? retorted the senior boy.
column3: Suppose you should turn out to be an everlasting big donkey? retorted the senior boy.
